title: When will the U.S. Senate confirm Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court?
preds: Democrats don’t have the votes to stop her
Senate will vote today, the Republicans have the votes to confirm her with or without the Democrats, so short of a meteor from outer space, I expect it will go through.

- Senate floor vote expected today. 
- 2 republicans look to side with democrats limiting debate to 30 hours clearing the path for approval at 1930 today.
- No reported COVID issues for the senate.
Updated given Senate's 10/25 vote 51-48 to advance Barrett's nomination.  Vote is expected 10/26.

"A divisive drive to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court before Election Day wound on Sunday toward its expected end, as Senate Republicans overcame Democratic protests to limit debate and set up a final confirmation vote for Monday." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/25/us/politics/amy-barrett-senate-vote.html
It is all but a done deal now

"Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, reversed course on Saturday and said that she now plans to vote in favor of Judge Amy Coney Barrett's final confirmation to the Supreme Court, which is expected to happen early next week ... Her vote in favor of Barrett all but ends any long shot hopes Democrats had of convincing some moderate and vulnerable Republicans to side against Barrett's confirmation." https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/supreme-court/murkowski-reverses-course-will-vote-confirm-barrett-supreme-court-n1244653

"Judge Amy Coney Barrett moved one step closer to a seat on the Supreme Court on Thursday as the Senate Judiciary Committee advanced her nomination with solely Republican support ... Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) is expected to take procedural steps Friday to bring her confirmation to the floor, with Barrett being confirmed by Monday evening, putting her in position to hear key cases involving potential election disputes and health care." https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/10/22/amy-coney-barrett-nomination-vote-live-updates/
Confirmation vote in Senate set for Monday, October 26, 2020 https://www.foxnews.com/politics/democrats-boycott-amy-coney-barrett-hearing

According to Transparency International, we achieved a rank of 23 out of 198 on their Corruption Perception Index in 2019.  Odds are pretty good we'll hit 50 for this year.  Stay tuned.

Barrett made it out of judiciary cmte this morning and expected to have a floor vote on Monday the 26th.  With only Collins and Murkowski as possible Republican defectors, I expect slim 51 vote confirmation.
-SJC  action complete. Action advances to Senate floor for Monday 26 OCT vote.
Seems like an almost certainty that ACB will be confirmed right now.
Worst case scenario based on senate rules, the latest the vote with take place is October 30. So, the vote will take place before November 3, and ACB is sure to be confirmed in that vote.
Updating based on hearings and scheduled vote this week.

- Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., announced he would put the nomination on the floor on Friday, October 23 which would lead to confirmation around 2627 October.
- Again, the only issue that could jeopardize the ruling is a COVID outbreak preventing Senators from voting on the floor.

Recent declarations by McConnell and Graham make it appear likely a full Senate vote will take place by the end of next week.  Barring a COVID outbreak that interrupts all Senate business or some procedural scheme by Democrats (all of which have failed so far in the committee process), it's highly likely Barrett will be confirmed before the election.
She cleared committee and the Covid outbreak in Senate appears contained

The hearings are now over, and the Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to approve her nomination on Oct 22 (the Democrats don't have enough votes to block it), and Mitch McConnell is expected to move for a full Senate vote on confirmation the week of Oct 26 (and again although there have been mutterings in the press that the Democrats are considering maneuvers to block her confirmation, there doesn't seem to be any clear mechanism they could use to do so). 
In short I am hard pressed to think of a scenario that would derail the confirmation happening prior to Election Day - it would have to be a real black swan.

Looks like all senators are out of quarantine.  Can’t see anything stopping it now unless someone was positive during the hearings and manages to spread it to everyone there.

No clear dissenters from the GOP at this point. Even early questions raised by Senators facing tough re-election battles appear to have dissipated. Hearings didn't appear to move the needle in either direction, which is not a surprise. Current timeline has the vote taking place the week of October 25th-32st, which leaves plenty of time to get the 51 votes done and dusted. Something huge would need to happen for this not to occur.
(no change) McConnell's pandemic relief votes will give those GOP senators up for election a tad bit of top cover before the ACB vote.

Still on track for a confirmation before Election Day. "The Senate Judiciary Committee will again meet to consider Barrett’s nomination at 1 pm ET on Thursday, Oct. 22 ... [it is] likely the Senate votes to end debate on the nomination on Monday, Oct. 26, or later in the week ... We believe the actual confirmation of Barrett won’t happen until the middle or end of the week of Oct. 25, likely Oct. 28-30." https://www.foxnews.com/politics/amy-coney-barrett-likely-confirmation-schedule-supreme-court

"The Senate Judiciary Committee has formally set a panel vote on Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination to the Supreme Court for Oct. 22 at 1 p.m. Eastern ... McConnell made it clear that Republicans will move expeditiously to confirm Barrett to the Supreme Court. 'We have the votes,' McConnell told reporters in Kentucky ... McConnell said that after the Oct. 22 committee vote, the full Senate would consider the nomination beginning Oct. 23." https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/10/15/amy-coney-barrett-confirmation-hearing-live-updates/

With the hearing concluding today, the nomination looks likely to get a vote prior to Nov. 3rd.. "The session will begin with senators taking turns stating their views of Judge Barrett and a move by Republicans to advance her nomination to the full chamber. By committee rules, Democrats may request that the vote be delayed a week, and they are expected to do so. Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and the panel’s chairman, has said he will honor the request in line with the committee’s custom. That would put the committee’s vote to approve Judge Barrett’s nomination on Oct. 22. A vote on confirmation by the full Senate is expected the following week, as early as Oct. 26."
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/15/us/politics/amy-coney-barrett-hearing.html

FYI/background from The Economist:
“Today the Senate Judiciary Committee convenes to consider Amy Coney Barrett, President Donald Trump’s nominee to replace the late liberal justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on America’s Supreme Court. The confirmation hearing for Ms Barrett, a conservative appeals-court judge, will be the first for a SCOTUS seat to be held partially by video-conference. At least two Republican committee members have tested positive for covid-19 and will participate virtually. Over the coming days senators will probe Ms Barrett’s views on matters including health care and abortion, and may press her to explain whether a letter she signed urging “the unborn to be protected in law” means she would jettison Roe v Wade . If, as expected, Ms Barrett gets the committee’s nod, a full Senate vote will follow in late October. Mr Trump hopes to seat his nominee before the election, but infected Republicans might complicate this plan. Senate rules require this tally to take place in person.“

Time to update my forecast. My previous forecast was Oct 1, 2020 12:08PM. There is nothing like a good stress to test ones forecast.  Since I forecast, Trump got Covid and so has much of the Republican party leaders including 3 members of the Senate judiciary committee. So if there was any event that could trigger any forecast to "flip" this should be it. I may not have forecast this exact scenario, but I did consider tail events and took that it into account in my original analysis.  My original forecast said 
"b) An event happens that slows things down.
There is no reason why any external event will slow things down. Even if Covid goes up a lot, the GOP will be very motivated to make sure this happens at full speed. 0% to this countermove." So now Covid has happened and it spread much more among Senior Republicans than many could have considered possible. However, despite this the GOP have said they are determined to stick to their original timetable and I still cannot see any logistical hurdle that cannot be overcome by sheer political will as per my original forecast. The logistical hurdles seem to be that an in person vote must take place in the last week of October and 3 Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee have Covid so must self-isolate. Without those 3 votes, the Reps may lose. However, there is nearly a month between them contracting Covid and that vote, so plenty of time for some or all of those Reps to recover in time. Further, there is no legal reason why the vote must be in person. There are political reasons such as "it's so important that doing it in person rather than online is a must" yackety yack. Except that not a single Republican genuinely intends to listen to a single word of that hearing. It's all a farce from start to finish with the outcome determined by Trump and Mitch McConnel in advance. The probability of a single senator Rep or Dem being in any way swayed by even the most damning evidential fact is almost 0.  So there is no truthful reason to prevent an absentee or online vote. The Reps therefore can and if necessary will simply change the voting rules. So I can't see how even a shock as large as this will make any difference to the time table, so my forecast remains stable and flip resistant.  My way of judging forecasting accuracy differs a bit from the conventional GJO approach. In addition to Brier, I use an approach I call "back-testing". I observed I accounted for the possibility of this shock (including a Covid related shock). I observe the impact of the shock in my updated forecast remains what I said it would be in my original forecast. I conclude my original forecast passed a "back-test".
Agree with @Jtrusz 's well-articulated reasoning. Senate rules are guidelines for them. Physical presence for the vote will not end up being a factor
McConnell is laser-focused on getting this done. This is the culmination of years-long efforts to reshape the court. I'm struggling to find reasons why they won't get this done.

- Senate has explicitly rejected fewer than 2 percent of all cabinet nominees since 1789, nearly a quarter of all Supreme Court nominations have failed to be confirmed. (Base rate 75%)
- Supreme Court Justices are confirmed by the Senate via a simple majority 
- Republicans have a 53-47 majority (+)
-Senators Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, have said they oppose holding a vote to confirm a Supreme Court justice before the election (51-49)
-  If 3 senators (COVID) are unable to vote (must be physically present to vote ) Barrett will not be confirmed (-)
- 3 senate judiciary senators are in quarantine
- VP is the tiebreaker in the event of a split (for Barrett)
-According to the Congressional Research Service, the average number of days from nomination to final Senate vote since 1975 is 67 days (2.2 months), while the median is 71 days (or 2.3 months) (-)
- Barrett was nominated on 26 Sep, 38 days before the election (-)
- Confirmation hearing planned for 12 Oct and vote on 22 Oct (+)
- Senate is projected to be split or flip to Democrate (a vote after 3 nov would be highly unlikely in this case)

Now, taking into account the fact that McConnell is under even more pressure to jam through Barrett's nomination, but balancing that with the fact that the Democrats will try to use the COVID infections to block a vote, I'm increasing the chances of her confirmation before Nov 3 somewhat, but not by too much.

- There are 22 members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.  Currently three Republican Senators have tested positive for COVID-19 (two on the committee).  It's possible that other senators may test positive in the coming days (the following senators also attended the 9/25 White House event - Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse, Tennessee Sen. Marsha Blackburn and Idaho Sen. Mike Crapo).  
- Senator McConnell said he plans to reconvene the Senate on October 19, given the spread of the virus and the Senate's work on Judge Barrett's nomination will continue October 12.  However, it's unclear if Democrats will agree that this is a safe timeframe to prevent further infection.   
- Republicans may not have the numbers to approve Barrett.  They have a 53–47 majority in the Senate, but Senators Collins and Murkowski said they would oppose a vote before the election, which means this could be pushed to the lame duck session. https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/about/faq
https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/10/supreme-court-trump-covid/616608/

I saw that she tested positive for coronavirus so I extended the time line.   Right now Lindsey Graham said her nomination would leave the judiciary committee on October 22.   This would leave about 2 weeks for the senate to vote.  However, the vote would likely occur that week since senators would need to campaign the week before the election and Republican senators in close elections would not want to vote for a conservative justice just days or hours before  the election. A lame duck vote days or  a week after the election is legal and could occur early enough for Barrett to vote in any election cases.  It would also lesson swing state senate election problems.  Senators like Collins could say one thing before the election and then change her mind right after the election without consequences, especially if she loses.    A positive coronavirus test would almost certainly delay the committee hearings since Barrett could too sick and might infect committee members.   No sooner than I clicked "submit" I saw a new article stating that she tested positive last summer.  Therefore, she is probably fine right now to attend the hearings and participate in the process. I doubt  the outside view  (about 67 days per @catherineN ) helps very much right now--given the lateness of the appointment and Trump's desire to overturn the popular vote.

Outside View:  
Decided to look first at: what is the average number of days (and median number of days) that pass between nomination and confirmation?
Per Wikipedia (which cites Congressional Research Service, which is an authoritative source): According to the Congressional Research Service, the average number of days from nomination to final Senate vote since 1975 is 67 days (2.2 months), while the median is 71 days (or 2.3 months).[19][20]   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appointment_and_confirmation_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20Congressional%20Research,days%20(or%202.3%20months). Interesting that the average # of days and the median # of days are very close.  Averaging those two figures together results in 69 days.  So let's take that as the Base Rate. Counting from today, Oct 2nd, 69 days in the future = Dec 10, 2020.   Inside view:
There's some possibility that the base rate of 69 days between nomination and confirmation could be affected by the politicization of the process.   Same website as above notes:  Before 1981 the approval process of Justices was usually rapid. From the Truman through Nixon administrations, Justices were typically approved within one month. From the Reagan administration to the present, however, the process has taken much longer. .... Some believe this is because Congress sees Justices as playing a more political role than in the past.[21]  
So I could imagine a delay in Barrett's confirmation due to the fraught political climate of the Trump administration, not to mention COVID issues... and also (per same Wikipedia article), the Senate is less likely to confirm a nominee submitted in the final year of a president's term.

With senate votes 'in the bag and counted' there is no reason for the confirmation not to happen. The Majority leader and numerous senators have stated this is perfectly legitimate, and much as they might try, there is nothing the Democrats can do to stop it. The only thing that matters is the life-time appointment of another SC judge.
I suspect the vote would confirm even if something horrific were found during the hearings.

Despite COVID setbacks, the Republican Party is determined to finish the process for the new SCOTUS before what is anticipated to be a challenged election.  The Republicans have the required votes to do so despite two Republicans indicating they would vote against.  If some sort of delay does occur, she will likely be confirmed prior to 5 Jan due to the political climate.

First, recent reports indicate that the Senate is likely to hold a vote to confirm Judge Barrett prior to the November 3, 2020 election and the November 10, 2020 oral argument in California v. Texas. Second, in the event Judge Barrett has not been confirmed prior to November 10, 2020 and the current eight justices are split on this matter, it is more likely the Court will re-hear the case after a new justice is seated. A re-hearing would be consistent with the Court’s practice in several close cases in 2016 after the death of Justice Scalia left the Court with eight members for about a year. Source: https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/california-v-texas-the-new-supreme-95579/ Connected to the Cal vs. Tex Supreme Court case and its possible outcome.

This is a good "chess like" forecasting question. There is no doubt the Republicans will reject their past principles and elect the new judge. The timing is harder.  Possible moves:
A) The senate elect the new judge after the election.
They can then wait and see who wins. This can give them more legitimacy and they will not be seen going to the electorate just after they have abandoned all their principles for naked political gain. But the new judge will not have a say on the election itself.
Follow-up moves:
If Trump wins and the GOP wins the senate, they will argue a mandate has been granted and will appoint the new judge immediately. They could delay safely, but the mandate means there is no need to do so. They will then immediately appoint the new judge. In addition, by keeping the justice appointment on the ballot, it could motivate conservative voters who were thinking of not voting for Trump but might for the new judge. If Trump wins but the GOP lose the senate, they can still claim a mandate to appoint the new judge and argue they stayed true to their principles. The Dems will dispute it, but they were going to appoint the judge anyway and having some legitimate justification is better than having none.
If Trump loses but the GOP keep the senate, the same as above.
If Trump loses and the GOP lose the senate, they will at full speed appoint the new judge knowing they can still publicly abandon their principles given the next Senate election is 2 years away. Either way, all roads lead to appointing before 5 January.  B) The senate elect the new judge before the election. They will have the electorial disadvantage of publicly abandoning their principles before a presidential and senate election increasing the chances of them losing both.
In return, they get their judge in place to decide any controversial issues on the vote itself, potentially skewing the rules of the game in their favour.
However conservatives turning off Trump will lose their motivation to vote GOP or for Trump, while Democrats will be rallied up for this issue to enable impeachment and expanding the Supreme Court to counter-act this bad behavior. 
In addition, GOP senators will spend their time in the Senate rather than campaigning, potentially costing them even more.
The fact is though that the justices, even the new proposed justice, do seem to have more loyalty to the law than to Trump or the GOP themselves. The idea that they will simply whitewash any case Trump or the GOP throws at them even a case aimed at outright stealing a democratic election I think is low. Instead, the main threat is to abortion and the ACA, not electoral integrity.  But this nuance is lost on Trump and many of the GOP senators. And notwithstanding this, they will still get a slightly more favorable ear for genuine legal disputes as opposed to outright fraud.  Both sides know this is going to the Courts because Trump has refused to respect a democratic vote, so I think the temptation to help the GOP in Court action will be too high and I don't think a legal analysis of the strength of the case they seek to put to the judge has been factored into their thinking. Many of them, Trump in particular, think courts will vote similarly to the way the Senate or the House does. We can now observe if A or B happens, there is no motivation for confirming Amy Barrett after 5 January so we set this outcome to 0%.  The correct move I think is to impose the new judge in the lame duck period because the relative legal advantage of having a "conservative" judge in place before the election is small, but the electoral cost will be much higher. However, Trump has very poor political judgment, as does his entire team, and the Senate GOP have been much more zealous recently and probably don't have the power to stop Trump even if they wanted to. And Trump supporters will certainly not see the big picture game and will be angry if the new judge is not in place by election day as they are convinced a conservative judge will always side with the GOP rather than the law. So Trump's team are not strong players and will make mistakes. The evidence shows Trump is pushing the nomination at the fastest possible speed, formally making the nomination by this Saturday. This is the action that could only be motivated by trying to make move B. However, while it keeps B in play, it doesn't rule out A, so it could be simply holding the ball up until a later date before making the final decision. The new Justice is also speedily arranging meetings with Senators, the GOP have made public statements saying they believe they should appoint the new judge as soon as possible. But these statements are still reversible, as they could say as soon as possible means the lame duck period. Conclusion, 5% chance the GOP and Trump will play the optimum move, 95% they are trying to appoint immediately. C) Counter moves
a) GOP and Trump cannot appoint the judge before January if they lose the vote in the Senate. 
The GOP majority is 53-47. We need 3 to flip. 1 said they will, 1 said they will and seems to be getting cold feet. Nobody else has declared. And the Senate majority leader is acting like he is very confident in getting the numbers.  I give a 2% chance of losing that vote, and 1% chance a second vote will win before January (1% each to both brackets). b) An event happens that slows things down.
There is no reason why any external event will slow things down. Even if Covid goes up a lot, the GOP will be very motivated to make sure this happens at full speed. 0% to this countermove. c) A procedural event happens that slows things down.
The only thing I can think of is a law case that creates an injunction on the Senate even if temporary. But I can't see any court doing that. The democratically elected chamber has the legitimacy to decide when and how it does its business and its not for the Court to interfere in that without a clear constitutional law being violated. I'll attach 0% probability. Summing the above yields my forecast.

With Senator Romney and Sens. Garder and McSally (both on the ballot in 2020) signaling their support for moving forward with ACB, that appears to pave the way for her confirmation by the Senate. The larger question now is the timing of the nomination. It appears that the Republican caucus is prepared to move rapidly with her nomination. She has already visited 19 Republican Senators in her first two days of hill meetings (a tradition among nominees is to offer a meeting to every sitting Senator). Although Democrats are still deciding on their tactics for how to handle the situation, they do not hold any silver bullet to stop the train and few options to slow it down. With the books cleared of other legislative issues (other than coronavirus relief), it would appear we are on track for mid-Oct hearings. This would likely set up a floor vote in mid-to-late October. Given the possibility of election court challenges, this would seem to increase the likelihood of a quick nomination. The only possibility for a lame-duck confirmation would likely be from Senators on the ballot in 2020 with close races. Spending time in Washington and not on the campaign trail could cause some concern among those Senators but seems unlikely to slow things down enough to slip pass the elections.

Only once in the last 50 years has a nomination failed when the President's party controls the Senate (Harriet Miers). Eventual confirmation is virtually assured. Media report that the Republican leadership in the Senate intends to move quickly with an eye toward a full Senate confirmation vote in late October. Given Barrett's recent (2017) confirmation for an appellate court seat, it seems unlikely significant new information will come to light that might sway at least two more Republican senators not to vote for her. However, it is possible depending on election polls in October, the Republican Senate leadership may seem some advantage in delaying the confirmation vote beyond the election. I think this is unlikely but possible. - 37 of 163 (22.6%) formal nominations to the Supreme Court have failed for any reason. (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/nominations/SupremeCourtNominations1789present.htm)
- Since 1970, there have been 23 nominations of which 5 (21.7%) failed for any reason. One of the 5 was John Roberts whose nomination for associate justice was withdrawn so he could be nominated for chief justice. 
- Since 1970, only twice has a nomination failed for any reason (Miers and Roberts) when the President's party controlled the Senate. Roberts doesn't really count.
- No SCOTUS nominees has ever been confirmed this close the an election. (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/27/us/politics/senate-supreme-court-nominee.html)
- However, NYT also reports the Senate Judiciary Committee intends to conduct quick hearings with the intent of holding a full Senate vote before November 3. A majority of Senators (all Republican) have signaled their willingness to confirm Trump's nominee.
- Consideration: Senate Republican leadership may not be as adamant about obtaining confirmation before the election as President Trump. Their interests may be slightly misaligned. That being said, Barrett was confirmed for an appellate court seat in 2017, it seems unlikely new information will come to light that would give Republican senators pause.
